utterances: Yeah.
I get 188 euro a week, which is the maximum amount you can get.
That would be about $250.
And to answer your question, I would actually take another job that isn't my ideal job.
I mean, I need money as much as anyone else does, so once I can find a job that is more benefit to me than staying on the dole, then I'd be more than willing to take that job.
What kinds of other jobs are you considering?
Typical unskilled work - you know, working in a convenience store or retail store, clothes store.
Even if it's minimum wage and full time, I'll get more money than I'm getting now, and it'll be worthwhile.
And it'll get me out of the house because I don't know how some people are willing to stay on welfare benefits for so long, because it's driving me mad.
Is it really?
I love having something to do, have a plan for the day - you know, go out and do it.
And not having a job is just - I wouldn't go as far to say depressing but, you know, it's not brilliant just sitting around doing nothing.
And when you say get you out of the house, it's your parents' house, right?
You've moved back in with your parents?
Yes.
Yeah, well, I can't afford to live by myself.
What would be some things that you might have figured you could afford to do before that now, you just don't because you don't have a job?
Well, I would've, potentially, bought a car - although that is completely off the cards right now.
So I cycle everywhere.
So no car.
What else?
To go out to the pub and have a drink - in Dublin, at least - an average pint will set you back about 5 euro and 20 cent.
Wow, more than $7.
And so you can understand why more and more people are sort of staying at home and having a few friends over to drink, instead of going out and partying the night away.
Do you think the economic uncertainty that you're dealing with, Adam, takes a psychological toll on you in some way?
It's - I try to stay optimistic.
It's not ideal but things could always be worse, you know.
There are a lot of people that are worse off than I am.
And so I don't like to sort of let it get me down.
Is that what keeps you going?
Yeah.
As far as I'm concerned, you know, things could be a lot worse.
I could be homeless.
I could, potentially, not have enough money to eat.
But I'm doing OK.
I have enough money to keep me going and, you know, things will pick up.
Adam Carpenter, we wish you the best of luck.
Thanks so much for talking with us.
Thank you very much for having me talk with you.
I appreciate it.
That's Adam Carpenter in Dublin.
The unemployment rate in Greece is even worse than in Ireland - 17 percent.
And for young people, a staggering 40 percent.
Michael Iliakis got his doctorate in ancient history last year.
He wants to teach classics.
He's 35.
He lives in Athens and has been sending out a blizzard of applications.
I've actually lost count.
It should be somewhere between 40 and 80.
Mm-hmm.
And any positive signs coming back?
No boom, no bust.
Here's Karl Case.
Muhammad Yunus, again, congratulations.
Thank you so much for being with us today.
Well, her brother, first of all, went to Princeton and - her older brother - and certainly, he introduced her to that.
Her parents were always very firm about going to college and doing the best that you can.
She was a good student.
She went to Whitney Young Magnet School on Chicago's Southside, which is a very prestigious school, a school where many students do well.
So, it would not have been unusual for anybody to come out of Whitney Young and go to Princeton, because that happens.
You mentioned her brother, who will be introducing her tonight at the Democratic Convention.
Tell us a little bit about him.
Well, he basically grew up very close with Michelle.
He is now the head basketball coach at the University of Oregon.
They are still very close and probably one of her closest confidantes and closest friends, even today.
Would she be surprised to hear herself described as a member of the elite?
She would because Michelle doesn't really see herself that way.
She like - as I said before, she sees herself as really a typical working woman who's raising a family.
Certainly, you know, people who went to Princeton are looked upon in a certain way.
But for her it's just the continuation of her lifelong education.
It was the next step for her, so basically her roots are what drives her now.
Did she see herself as an outsider at Princeton and Harvard Law?
She talks often about how she had difficulty fitting in early on at Princeton.
Being one of the few African-Americans there at the time, but that experience was not unlike any experience - many African-Americans feel whey they go to predominantly white schools.
But she adjusted to that early on and did well, and went on, after that, to Harvard Law.

We're talking with Dahleen Glanton of the Chicago Tribune about Michelle Obama, who will introduce herself to many Americans tonight when she speaks at the Democratic convention in Denver, the Democratic convention that will later this week nominate her president - her husband to be president of the United States.
If you would like to join us, 800-989-8255, email is talk@npr.org Let's begin with Jeffrey.
Jeffrey calling us from New London in Connecticut.
Hi.
Thanks for taking my call.
Go ahead, please.
My question is - about three months ago Mrs. Obama kind of committed a little foot in mouth disease with her comment that it was her first time that she was proud to be an American.
And my question is, what about her youth and her upbringing, are the roots of that comment?
What was it that she found so displeasing about America that it took her, you know, 40 something years to get to that point where she was proud to be an American?
First time in her adult life that she was proud to be an American referring to her president's - through her husband's presidential campaign.
Dahleen Glanton?
Well, Michelle has said repeatedly that that comment was misinterpreted.
It's not very difficult for many African-Americans to understand what she was talking about.

Because simply growing up in neighborhoods where you've never seen an African-American get this far in many aspects of life, in particular to be nominated for president, is something that you grow up thinking might never happen.
You hear all the time that it could happen.
That's what the civil rights movement was all about.

But even for those people who were a part of the civil rights movement they're still surprised, they're still in awe, still in a little bit of shock that it happened because nobody really believed that America was quite ready to make this happen.

A lot of people expressed incredulity that somebody of her age was not proud of her county when the Berlin Wall came down, when the United States - which the United States, they did so much to do and liberated all of those people in Central and Eastern Europe would have been under a Communist heel for decades.
Things like that, did she learn from this experience, do you think?
That, that when she says something today she's not just saying it to a small group of people.
Absolutely.
She has learned a lot and become must more savvy with her presentation as this campaigned has gone on.
It's been a learning experience for her.
During, you know, her husband's candidacy - when he was running for the State Senate and for the U.S.
Senate - it wasn't this kind of spotlight on her.
So, it's - it was so difficult at first but she seems to have weathered it a lot better now.
Hmm.
Do you think it's equivalent to, I think it was Hillary Clinton 16-years ago I guess saying, well, gee, she wasn't one those women who stayed home and baked cookies.
We'll absolutely.
The only difference in that was that Hillary Clinton at that time had been wife of a governor for a long time.
So, certainly, being in a national spotlight is a lot different than being in the state spotlight.
But I think for any potential first lady, it's a difficult at process and it's something that you just have to get used to and learn how to say the right thing at the right time.
Jeffrey?
I think Jeffrey has left us.
But anyway, thanks very much for the phone call.
And before the emails continue, we misspoke, her brother coaches at Oregon State University in Corvallis not the University of Oregon.
So, we correct ourselves.
Thank you very much for that.
Let's see if we can get another caller on the line.
This is Bobby.
Bobby with us from Jacksonville in Florida.
Yes I am independent and as of (unintelligible) we're leaning towards voting for John McCain.
But I like Michelle Obama.
I think she's charismatic.
I like to hear her speak, I hadn't planned on watching the Democratic National Convention but I'm going to watch it tonight since I heard she's going to be the keynote speaker.
And as far as the Un-American comment, it makes me angry that people are not (unintelligible) saying she wasn't proud to be an American at some point in time.
You know, I don't think that's such a bad thing because as a gay man sometimes I'm not proud to be an American.
And I don't think that makes you a bad person.
And I just think she's refreshingly honest, and I really, really like her.
She really fascinates me.
Bobby, thanks very much for the call.
Drive carefully, please.
Thank you very much.
